inference: Per-session comfort–efficiency profile with verified presence
Description: For each usage log session, intersect its duration with periods of continuous proximity and analyze the corresponding flow rate and temperature; this yields a comfort–efficiency profile showing how much water and heat is used while a user is actually present under their chosen temperature.
short rationale: Profiles comfort and resource use tied to presence and temperature, revealing individual habits.

inference: Cold-start waste with user waiting for warm water
Description: When proximity shows a user has arrived and a session has started, measure flow volume from the flow history until temperature reaches the user’s typical comfort band; this volume is cold-start waste incurred while the user waits near the fixture.
short rationale: Captures waiting behavior and comfort band, moderately exposing user experience.

inference: Detection of water left running after user departure
Description: Within a usage session, identify intervals where flow remains above a threshold and temperature is stable, but proximity shows the user has left; this combination reveals water and energy wasted when the fixture is left running without anyone present.
short rationale: Shows water left on after departure, highlighting specific user lapses.

inference: True dwell time vs logged session length
Description: Compare the total session duration in usage logs with the interval from first to last proximity activation, then overlay flow and temperature; the difference shows how much of the logged session is actual user dwell with meaningful water use and at what temperature.
short rationale: Measures actual dwell vs logged time with comfort context, revealing detailed presence patterns.

inference: Hands-free vs manual usage patterns under thermal load
Description: Sessions where flow on/off transitions are tightly aligned with proximity activations and stable comfort temperature peaks indicate hands-free usage, whereas sessions with weaker proximity–flow timing but similar temperature patterns point to manual operation.
short rationale: Infers control style from presence/flow/temperature timing, modest behavioral insight.

inference: Two-phase shower segmentation (wash vs rinse) with presence confirmation
Description: In long sessions with continuous proximity, use flow spikes and temperature shifts to separate a hotter, possibly lower-flow wash phase from a slightly cooler or higher-flow rinse phase, providing a structured view of shower routines.
short rationale: Segments personal shower phases using presence, flow, and temperature, revealing routine details.

inference: Detection of efficient ‘water off while soaping’ behavior
Description: Within a session, look for intervals where proximity shows the user is present and temperature remains in the comfort band, but flow drops nearly to zero; these intervals indicate efficient behavior where users pause water while actively soaping or scrubbing.
short rationale: Flags conservation behavior during presence, profiling user efficiency choices.

inference: Detection of inefficient ‘standing under running water’ behavior
Description: Find periods where proximity indicates continuous presence, temperature is in the comfort range, and flow remains high without significant variation; such stretches indicate time spent mostly standing under running water with limited active washing.
short rationale: Identifies prolonged high-flow presence, exposing wasteful personal habits.

inference: Comfort temperature adaptation by time of day with presence-filtering
Description: Group sessions by time-of-day from usage logs, then only consider periods where proximity is active and flow is non-zero; temperature distributions in these windows reveal how users adjust comfort temperature at different times (e.g., hotter night showers).
short rationale: Reveals time-of-day comfort preferences tied to presence and use.

inference: Seasonal comfort and conservation tradeoff analysis
Description: Across seasons, compare sessions of similar duration and presence patterns; analyze whether users choose higher temperatures and longer durations (higher flow integration) in colder months, mapping how thermal comfort preferences affect water and energy usage.
short rationale: Seasonal comfort vs usage trends; aggregated but still reflects personal preferences over time.

inference: Per-user (or per-routine) comfort signature without explicit IDs
Description: Cluster sessions based on start times and durations (logs), presence patterns (continuous vs intermittent), typical flow trajectories, and temperature bands while proximity is active to infer distinct comfort signatures for recurring routines without needing explicit user identities.
short rationale: Builds implicit user/routine profiles from presence, flow, and temperature, strongly identifying behavior.

inference: Detection of short ‘test and adjust’ episodes before full use
Description: Identify short usage log entries where proximity is present, temperature changes rapidly, and flow is modest; these are test-and-adjust episodes that typically precede a later full-length session at a settled temperature.
short rationale: Spots brief pre-use testing behavior, modestly exposing routine starts.

inference: Estimating pre-use flushing volume guided by presence and temperature
Description: For each session, isolate the period after proximity begins and flow starts but before temperature stabilizes in the user’s comfort band; integrating flow here gives an estimate of flushing volume users incur to obtain clean or warm water.
short rationale: Quantifies flushing before comfort reached, reflecting user patience and habits.

inference: Detecting sensor misalignment via comfort-like usage without presence
Description: Sequences of stable warm temperature, typical shower-length flow profiles, and logged sessions that lack matching proximity activity suggest that the proximity sensor is misaligned or blind to the area where users actually stand during normal use.
short rationale: Primarily finds sensor blind spots; limited incremental personal exposure.

inference: Detecting nuisance proximity triggers with no hydraulic or thermal change
Description: Short proximity activations unaccompanied by session creation, meaningful flow changes, or temperature adjustments indicate nuisance triggers such as people walking by, which can be used to refine sensor sensitivity and field of view.
short rationale: Identifies false triggers without real use; low personal detail.

inference: Comfort stability index during continuous presence
Description: For each session, during intervals where proximity is continuously active and flow is above a minimum threshold, compute temperature variance; lower variance indicates stable thermal comfort as experienced by the user, while higher variance signals unstable mixing or heater control.
short rationale: Evaluates comfort stability during presence, reflecting user experience quality.

inference: Flow–temperature coupling under active presence
Description: Analyze how temperature changes in response to adjustments in flow only during periods with continuous presence; this reveals how well the system maintains comfort when users switch between strong and gentle spray while standing at the fixture.
short rationale: Assesses system response during presence; technical with limited behavioral profiling.

inference: Detection of pre-use safety checks for children
Description: Short sessions where a taller user presence is detected first, temperature is adjusted and tested with modest flow, then a second presence pattern suggests a smaller/shorter user, indicate parental pre-checking and adjustment of water temperature for children.
short rationale: Infers multi-person roles and child safety checks, highly sensitive interpersonal behavior.

inference: Differentiating cleaning vs personal hygiene via four-signal pattern
Description: Cleaning sessions exhibit irregular usage logs (multiple short entries), intermittent or moving proximity patterns, variable flow, and cooler or more variable temperatures, whereas hygiene sessions show fewer, longer logs, more stable presence, steadier flow, and warmer temperatures.
short rationale: Classifies activity type (cleaning vs hygiene) using presence, flow, and temperature, revealing routines.

inference: Quantifying energy-efficient behavior for comparable comfort
Description: For sessions with similar presence durations and comfort temperature bands, compare integrated flow volumes; lower volume for comparable presence and temperature indicates more water-efficient behavior (e.g., efficient shower vs wasteful shower).
short rationale: Compares resource use for similar comfort, profiling individual efficiency.

inference: Heat-loss characterization between consecutive presence events
Description: After a session with stable warm temperatures ends and proximity vanishes, track how long it takes for temperature to drop near baseline before the next presence event; this reveals pipe and fixture heat retention characteristics relevant to perceived comfort at next use.
short rationale: Focuses on system heat retention with minimal direct behavioral exposure.

inference: Identification of high-energy comfort routines
Description: Find recurring sessions where logs show similar timing and long durations, proximity is continuous, flow is moderate to high, and temperature is near the upper end of safe comfort; these indicate habitual, high-energy comfort routines like long hot evening showers.
short rationale: Highlights habitual long hot routines, revealing consistent user preferences.

inference: Detection of under-heated sessions with persistent presence
Description: Sessions where proximity remains active for long durations and flow is present, but temperature trends remain below the user’s usual comfort range, may indicate heater underperformance or supply issues that degrade comfort.
short rationale: Shows users enduring low comfort despite presence, indicating experience issues.

inference: User tolerance to thermal delay vs session abandonment
Description: Measure, for each session, time from first proximity detection to reaching comfort temperature, and check whether the session continues or is aborted; patterns where many sessions end before reaching comfort reveal low tolerance for thermal delay.
short rationale: Captures whether users abort sessions before comfort, revealing tolerance thresholds.

inference: Time-of-day dependent preheat recommendation
Description: For common session start times from usage logs, examine how long it takes to reach comfort temperature at typical flow while the user is present; if ramp-up is consistently slow at certain times, the system can preheat or recirculate before expected presence to reduce waiting.
short rationale: Uses habitual start times and ramp delays to adjust preheat, reflecting routine schedules.

inference: Recognition of ‘quick warm burst’ vs ‘extended mild shower’ patterns
Description: Compare sessions where proximity is short but temperature rises quickly to high levels with sessions where proximity is long and temperature is moderate; the two patterns represent quick intense warm bursts vs extended mild comfort routines.
short rationale: Distinguishes short hot bursts from longer mild sessions, indicating usage style.

inference: Comfort-preserving water reduction scenarios
Description: Simulate reduced flow scenarios using actual temperature trends and presence durations for past sessions; if lower flow preserves achieved comfort temperatures while the presence timeline from logs remains similar, water use could be reduced without sacrificing comfort.
short rationale: Scenario modeling with past presence/temperature; low incremental personal exposure.

inference: Detection of presence during high-temperature standby
Description: Periods with no ongoing session in logs but elevated outlet temperature and brief proximity events suggest users checking or being wary of an overly hot fixture before starting a session, hinting at perceived scald risk even prior to full use.
short rationale: Shows users approaching during hot standby, revealing caution and off-session presence.

inference: Adaptive child-safe mode activation
Description: When proximity patterns suggest a child (shorter, shorter presence) and usage logs show shorter sessions, automatically restrict allowed temperature range and, if flow curves show high rates, reduce maximum flow to enforce a safer child-friendly mode.
short rationale: Detects child presence to alter settings, directly tied to child-specific behavior.

inference: Estimating portion of session used for active washing
Description: Within each session, intersect intervals where proximity is active, flow exceeds a set threshold, and temperature is within comfort band; this subset represents true active washing time vs overall time spent in the bathroom with water barely used or off.
short rationale: Calculates active washing vs idle time during presence, indicating behavior efficiency.

inference: Context-aware reminders for conservation during hot routines
Description: For routines where logs, proximity, flow, and temperature show long, hot sessions with little variation, the system can trigger a gentle reminder after a characteristic duration, as the pattern indicates sustained high resource usage by a present user.
short rationale: Targets reminders based on identified long hot routines, profiling sustained usage.

inference: Detection of ‘shower running to heat room’ behavior
Description: Sessions where temperature and flow remain high for long durations, but proximity presence is intermittent or low after the initial phase, indicate users may be running hot water mainly to warm the bathroom rather than for continuous personal washing.
short rationale: Infers intentional hot-water use without presence, revealing non-hygiene behavior.

inference: Fair usage estimation in multi-user environments without accounts
Description: Cluster presence patterns and their associated session durations, flow volumes, and comfort temperatures to approximate distinct user-like profiles, allowing the system to estimate how much hot-water time and volume each implicit user profile consumes.
short rationale: Builds pseudo-user profiles from presence, flow, and temperature to estimate individual usage.

inference: Detection of pre- and post-session grooming windows
Description: Proximity activity before session start and after session end, with temperature remaining near comfort levels but flow off, identifies grooming time spent near the fixture without extra water use, informing design of lighting or mirror-related features.
short rationale: Reveals grooming periods around sessions, detailing personal routines.

inference: User comfort drift over months for stable routines
Description: For recurring sessions with similar duration and presence patterns (e.g., daily evening shower), track shifts in chosen comfort temperatures over months; gradual increases may indicate changing sensitivity or environmental factors.
short rationale: Tracks long-term comfort temperature shifts for recurring routines, profiling evolving preferences.
